We are given two programs to complete. For program1.py:
We are to cover an n x n board with half-queens (attacking same row, same column, and one diagonal: a-b=c-d) such that every cell is attacked by at least one half-queen, and we want the minimum number. The provided code has a structure for n<=2 and n==3, and then for n>=4 it uses a loop to compute some x and then appends positions in a specific pattern. The loop in the else part (for n>=4) is:
   for i in range(100000, -1, -1):
        if 3 * i + 2 <= n:
            # TODO: Your code here

We note that the condition 3*i+2 <= n is used to find the largest i (since we are going from 100000 down to 0) such that 3*i+2 <= n.

But note: the problem says n can be up to 10^5, so we are iterating backwards from 100000 to 0 to find the largest i satisfying 3*i+2<=n. We can set x = i, but note that the condition is 3*i+2<=n, so we break at the first i (which is the largest) satisfying that. After the loop, we have:
   z = 1
   for i in range(x):
        ans.append(" ".join(map(str, (z + x - i - 1, z + i))))
   z += x
   x += 1
   for i in range(x):
        ans.append(" ".join(map(str, (z + x - i - 1, z + i))))
   z += x
   for i in range((n - 2) % 3):
        ans.append(" ".join(map(str, (z + (n - 2) % 3 - i - 1, z + i))))

This is the cost added when we make k the root of [l, r]: the entire subtree [l, k-1] (which becomes the left child) will have its depth increased by 1 for every node in that subtree. Similarly for [k+1, r]. And the cost for the edges from the root to the two children is: 
   for every pair (i, j) such that i is in [l, k-1] and j is not in [l, k-1] (because if j is in [l, k-1] then the path between i and j is entirely within the left subtree and we don't add an extra edge for the root) -> but wait, the distance d[i,j] increases by 2 for every pair that has one in the left and one in the right? Actually, no: the entire path from any node in the left to any node in the right goes through the root, so each such pair will have an extra 2 in the distance (because the root is one extra step for both, so the path from left to right goes: left node -> root -> right node: 2 extra steps). But also, the root to the left child adds 1 to every node in the left, and the root to the right child adds 1 to every node in the right. Therefore, the total increase in cost when we make k the root is:

   = (sum_{i in [l, k-1]} sum_{j not in [l, k-1]} c[i][j]) + (sum_{i in [k+1, r]} sum_{j not in [k+1, r]} c[i][j])
